Problem Overview

In this problem, students will continue to look at relationships between variables and will write equations to represent the relationships. Like Problem 3.1, this problem has been designed to develop students’ ability to write algebraic expressions for single-operation relationships. Students solve problems by writing and solving equations in the form of x + p = q.

Use the introduction to the investigation to discuss the steps for writing an equation. The steps generalize students’ thinking about the relationships between variables in both tables and words into writing an equation.

Discuss the example in the student text, which shows how to write a rule for the income generated: first try a few examples using the relationship between the variables; next describe the relationship in words; and finally write an equation with single-letter variables.

The text also discusses the convention of leaving out the multiplication sign when multiplying a number by a variable or when multiplying two variables. So for example, you can write 350 × n as 350n. You can either read through the example or present the information about admission costs to students and ask questions to help them develop the equation as a group.

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

In this problem, students will continue to look at relationships between variables and will write equations to represent the relationships.

It may be helpful for some students to review the steps for writing equations that were found in Problem 3.1:

  1. Step 1. Try a few examples with the relationship between the variables.

After subtracting 15 from the left side of the equation, you could ask:

  • What should you do to keep the two sides equal? (Subtract 15 from the right side.)

Repeat this method for each of the questions in the Introduction. Then have students try their methods on another example of equality.

  • What should you do to keep the two sides equal? (Equality is maintained by adding, subtracting, multiplying, or dividing each side by the same number. For multiplication and division, the number must be nonzero.)

You could introduce that these are called the Properties of Equality or wait until the introduction of Problem 3.3.

Discuss equivalent expressions and the Distributive property. The expressions 2x + 4, 2(x+2), and x + 2 + x + 2 are equivalent expressions. Note that you can apply the Distributive Property to the expression 2x + 4 to write 2(x + 2) so 2 x + 4 = 2(x + 2).

  • What properties of operations could you use to show that x = 2 = x = 2 = 2(x + 4)? (Answers will vary)

Presenting the Challenge

If you did not make the transition from pouches and coins to variables and numbers at the end of the Summarize for Problem 3.1, do so now. Be sure students have a general idea of the procedures. You might want to revisit one of the situations from Problem 3.1. As a part of the discussion, discuss how the pouches and coins can be represented by various equivalent expressions.

You might want to add to the instructions of the Initial Challenge by having students write their steps for solving, showing what is happening with the pouches and coins. Then next to each step write the equation symbolically.

Have students begin this problem independently and then work with a partner to compare their thinking.
